From there Leah started to engage the greater UX community in Toronto and beyond and helped double the size of the Toronto UX team, increasing gender diversity by 50%.

Before joining Shopify, Leah worked at several nonprofits for the better part of a decade where her accomplishments included developing a microfinance program for social enterprises, fundraising $4.3M in Community Bond sales for the Centre for Social Innovation, and building an accelerator program for entrepreneurs focused on solving social and environmental challenges. Leah is currently on maternity leave with her baby June and loves talking about UX when she’s not pushing a stroller around High Park and Roncesvalles.

Mark Farmer is a digital communications professional with over 15 years’ experience working for non-profits and commercial enterprises, one-person shops and large multinational corporations in Canada and abroad. He specializes in digital strategy, social media, accessibility and user experience design. Mr. Farmer started in web design and development in the late ‘90s with TransCanada PipeLines, and founded his own shop, webness, in 2001. He spent five years as webmaster and then creative director for Earth Day Canada, before shifting to digital communications for organizations such as the Royal Ontario Museum, Intuit’s Global Business Division and York University. Currently he is the senior digital strategist at the Ontario College of Teachers. Mr. Farmer is the founder of the Toronto Museums & Culture Online Collective, co-founder of Social Media Café Toronto, and is a regular presenter at industry events and at colleges and universities around Toronto.

Marsha Brown is the Global Learning Leader at Hatch Ltd. She uses modern learning approaches and technology to help business leaders improve their team’s learning culture and develop the skills of their employees in support of business goals. She draws on her strengths in learning experience design, change management, communications and learning technology and data analytics to bring success to the projects she leads. Marsha obtained her BA in Information Technology and certificate in Technical writing, from York University and is currently working towards her certificate in Human Resources Management.

As an avid learner herself, she is passionate about the impact modern learning interventions have on employee performance and is driven to inspire others to reach their full potential through learning. As a certified training and development professional (CTDP) since 2015, Marsha has strong technical knowledge and over 10 years’ experience driving learning in sectors such as automotive, retail, HR, finance and professional services in both national and global organizations.

My first “real job” was in Technical writing, around that time I started a side gig in freelancing as a creative media designer and developer – learning and development weren’t even a twinkle in my eye back then.

It wasn’t until I was “borrowed” for an assignment writing a job aid on how to access the company LMS, that my passions collided. This is where my learning design journey began.

Since then I have spent well over a decade honing my craft in learning experience design in industries ranging from automotive to financial services and now, tech.

Today I lead a team of brilliant Learning Experience Designers at Shopify.

I get a flutter in my heart when discovering and testing creative, practical, non-traditional approaches to learning design – especially digitally – to meet learners where they truly learn best.

Rebecca Shevel is a dedicated and innovative Marketing Director, Media, and Advertising leader with +20 years of experience growing brands, audiences, and revenue. She has done this by developing relationships, creating multi-platform marketing, content & strategic advertising solutions. Rebecca’s approach is to be consultative, strategic, and holistic with her clients and team.

Rebecca passions include content marketing, digital media, and emerging technology. She has extensive experience working directly with clients (B2B & B2C), boutique and national media agencies. Rebecca brings a unique view when solving business challenges, having worked on the media supplier and agency sides of business. Rebecca enjoys helping define KPIs for clients to ensure the recommended strategy is fully supported by the best content, marketing, and digital tactics.

Rebecca has worked with and for numerous Tier-1 brands in a variety roles. Currently, she is the Director of Marketing and Custom Solutions at Fifth Story, working with the Account Directors to help create an array of content marketing and digital solutions for clients; while also focused on building the Fifth Story brand via partnerships, sponsorships, PR, and targeted marketing.

Alison is an experienced social worker and mediator who has specialized in the field of ADR (family) for over 20 years. She has been a Roster Mediator in Durham Region, the Staff Mediator at the North York Family Court, and the Acting Coordinator for Family Mediation Services and Family Law Information Centres for the Ministry of the Attorney General. Alison has also worked as a Child Protection Mediator and is passionate about and trained in child-inclusive mediation and counselling.

Alison has over 30 years of experience working in family, child welfare and youth courts, counselling, and research settings. She brings expertise in working with survivors and perpetrators of domestic violence as well as with people with disabilities. Currently, Alison is in private practice offering services as a mediator, collaborative family professional, parent coordinator and counsellor.

Alison has been a Committee Member of the Toronto High Conflict Forum and has provided mentorship and job shadowing opportunities for law and social work students. She has presented at the North York Family Law Bar Education Series. Alison holds a Master of Social Work degree (University of Toronto) as well as Bachelor’s degrees in Social Work (York University) and Criminology (Carleton University).

Archana is a Certified Family Law Specialist and accredited Family Mediator practicing in Toronto, who brings over 20 years of international experience in family dispute resolution. As a Panel Lawyer for the Office of the Children’s Lawyer, Archana has worked on issues of gender-based violence, child abuse and child protection through representing primarily vulnerable populations including immigrants, refugees, women, and children in high conflict family matters and at all levels of the court system. She believes that culturally appropriate services are crucial for families navigating any dispute resolution process and that diversity and inclusion are key to advancing peace.

Archana is a member of the leadership team of Mediators Beyond Borders International, an international NGO that holds consultative status with the United Nations. She currently serves as a Board Member with the Association of Family & Conciliation Courts – Ontario. Archana is a co-author of the book “Domestic Violence in Immigrant Communities: Case Studies,” which examines the experiences of immigrant and refugee women who have experienced domestic violence, based on analysis of closed legal cases filed in Ontario family courts. Archana’s awards and distinctions include “The Volunteer Service Award” from the Ontario Ministry of Citizenship and Immigration.

Avagene is a Family Law Lawyer, Accredited Family Mediator and Notary Public who has practised exclusively in family law since her 2005 call to the Ontario Bar. Avagene is the founder of Skervin Law, a family law firm in Mississauga, Ontario. She promotes the resolution of family law issues including decision-making responsibility, parenting time, support and property, through a variety of alternate dispute resolution processes. She is also a member of the Ontario Family Law Limited Scope Services Project and sits as a Dispute Resolution Officer at the Superior Court of Justice, Family Court Branch. Her extensive mediation experience includes working as an on-site mediator in Toronto’s family courts.

Avagene’s volunteer work in the field of family dispute resolution includes having served on the Board of Directors for Family Dispute Resolution Institute of Ontario (FDRIO) and being the current Co-Chair of the Diversity and Inclusion Committee for FDRIO. She has also shared her expertise in family law by presenting on “The Intersection of the Pandemic and Family Law Cases, A Financial and Legal Review” at the Chartered Business Valuators Institute (CBV), among other presentations.

Avagene holds a Bachelor of Laws degree (Honours) and a Bachelor of Arts degree in French (Honours) as well as a French Business Certificate issued by the Chambre of Commerce and Industry of Paris.

As a litigator, Barb has appeared at all levels of court, including the Supreme Court of Canada and a wide variety of statutory and appellate tribunals. For the last 20 years, Barb has focused her practice on mediation and arbitration and has experience in a broad range of areas including bodily injury, errors and omissions, property claims, construction, property and commercial leasing, employment, WCB, OHS, privacy and discrimination disputes.

Barb is a Distinguished Fellow of the International Academy of Mediators, Chartered Mediator and Chartered Arbitrator with the Alternate Dispute Resolution Institute of Canada, Member of the British Columbia Arbitration and Mediation Institute, Governor with the International Academy of Mediators, Registrant with the BC Mediator Roster Society, Certified Mediator with the International Mediation Institute, and Charter Member with the Canadian Academy of Distinguished Neutrals. Barb has also served as a Judicial Justice of the Peace for the Provincial Court of British Columbia, and Appointee with the Panel of Arbitrators for the American Dispute Resolution Center.

Barb’s accolades are wide-reaching and extensive, including:

Canadian and International Who’s Who of Commercial Mediation, 2011 – 2022

Best Attorneys in Canada by Best Lawyers, 2013 and 2015

Lawyer of the Year (Alternative Dispute Resolution) by Lawyer Monthly, 2014 and 2021

Best Lawyers in British Columbia by Best Lawyers, 2016

Best Lawyers in Canada by the Vancouver Sun, 2018

Best Lawyer in Canada by Best Lawyers, 2018, 2020, 2021

Best Lawyers in Canada by the National Post, 2019 and 2020

Lawyer of the Year by the National Post and Best Lawyers, 2020

Barbara Benoliel is President of Preferred Solutions, a conflict management organization. She holds a B.A. (Hons) in Psychology, a M.B.Sc. In Organizational Behaviour and Development, and a Ph.D. in Criminal Justice. She is a licensed private detective in Ontario. Barbara has been in private practice for over 25 years, and mixes research, teaching, and practice.

Barbara is a past President of the ADR Institute of Ontario (ADRIO), and a winner of the Lionel McGowan Ontario award for contributions to the field of Alternative Dispute Resolution. She is a senior core faculty member at Walden University in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Her main practice is in human rights mediation and restorative processes in multiple settings. Her research focuses on the human side of disputes in organizations and institutions and alternative approaches to justice.

Ben has been an ADR professional for over a decade, and is currently the Senior Investigator for ADR Chambers, investigating workplace, municipal, and banking disputes. He is accredited as a Charted Mediator (C.Med.) and Chartered Arbitrator (C.Arb.) by the ADR Institute of Canada, and earned Law and Master’s of Business Administration degrees from the University of Toronto. He has been a member of the Ontario Bar since 2004.

Ben has extensive investigative and adjudicative experience municipally. He is the Integrity Commissioner for the City of Sarnia and the Town of Wasaga Beach through ADR Chambers and was the full-time Lead Investigator for Toronto’s Office of the Integrity Commissioner from 2017-19. Ben has been appointed by several municipalities as a By-law Hearing Officer, conducting formal hearings into by-law violations including parking, tree preservation, property standards, and animal control.

Ben has extensive experience in tribunal and community mediation settings. He was formerly a member of the Condominium Authority Tribunal and Toronto’s Administrative Penalty Tribunal, as well as a full-time Mediator and Arbitrator for insurance disputes regarding motor vehicle accidents.

Ben has served as a volunteer Community Mediator for St. Stephen’s Community House, Warden Woods Community Centre, and Conflict Mediation Services of Downsview, and currently volunteers as the Chair of the University of Toronto’s Complaint and Resolution Council for Student Societies. He is a former Director of the ADR Institute of Ontario.

Brenda has spent over 20 years honing her skills in the dispute resolution field as a mediator, trainer, facilitator, and conflict management coach. As an entrepreneur specializing in leadership communications, employee engagement and conflict management, Brenda launched Discussions by Design to provide support to both new and senior organisational leaders so that they can develop proactive, energized, and productive high performing teams with measurable results.

Brenda is a National Mediation Trainer and Coach for the ADR Institute of Canada (ADRIC) and served eight years as a Director and Executive Member for the ADR Institute of British Columbia (ADRBC). She is on Health Canada’s Informal Conflict Management Support (ICMS) Roster as a Conflict Management Expert to assist employees of the Federal Government address workplace issues using various dispute resolution processes such as mediation and individual and group conflict management coaching.

As a trainer and facilitator in communication and conflict management, Brenda incorporates the most advanced research and tools in neuroscience and relationship awareness to help organizational teams build greater awareness and skills to effectively manage difficult discussions and work through conflict. She co-developed and facilitated a program on Board Governance and Dispute Resolution which has been delivered internationally.

Brenda received her Certificate in Conflict Resolution from the Justice Institute of British Columbia, her Chartered Mediation (C. Med) designation through the ADR Institute of Canada, and her Certification in Executive Coaching from Royal Roads University.

Candice is a sole practitioner who specializes in all aspects of family law, including custody, access, support, division of property, equalization, and domestic contracts. Her niche is high conflict custody and access cases, particularly those involving domestic violence. Candice is a passionate client advocate with over 10 years of experience exclusively litigating family law matters at the Ontario Court of Justice and Superior Court of Justice.

Candice also sits on the Duty Counsel Panel at the Brampton Courthouse, where she provides legal assistance to self-represented family law litigants. Outside of the courtroom, Candice assists individuals to resolve disputes about family law issues as an Accredited Family Mediator with the Peel Family Mediation Service (PFMS). Candice holds a Professional Master of Laws (LL.M.) in Family Law from Osgoode Hall Law School.

Caroline is an accredited Family and Child Protection Mediator, a collaborative family professional and a Voice of the Child Practitioner. For more than a decade, Caroline’s work has focused on protecting parent-child relationships during the stressful separation period. Within the child protection context, Caroline has provided mediation services to parents experiencing intense conflict, to kinship caregivers and to adoptive and birth families negotiating openness arrangements. Caroline has provided mediation services through two court-connected mediation programs, provided information and referral services in the family court system, and continues to provide mediation services in her active private practice. Using her natural curiousity, warmth, and deep respect for people’s lived experience, Caroline is able to connect with parents and caregivers from diverse backgrounds and across different family structures and life stages.

Prior to working in this area, Caroline worked as a Child Protection Worker, a Child Protection Research Co-ordinator and a Roots of Empathy Instructor. In addition to helping others work through conflict, Caroline has raised two children, three dogs and a pair of ducklings. She is a scuba diving enthusiast.

Claudette is a Registered Social Worker and Accredited Family Mediator specializing in high-conflict dispute resolution. Her experience in family mediation, child protection mediation, and parenting coordination has made her a sought-after practitioner.

In addition to managing her private practice, Claudette provides mediation services for two court-connected programs. She previously served as a Panel Clinician with the Office of the Children’s Lawyer, providing Section 112 custody and access reports. As a family professional, Claudette’s main objective is to empower parents to reach agreements in their children’s best interests. She has extensive experience in child welfare and has worked extensively with medically fragile and high-needs children and youth. She is a member of several rosters, including the Ontario Child Protection Mediation, Family Group Conferencing and Family Dispute Resolution Institute of Ontario. Claudette is also an active volunteer in community mediation and has assisted landlords and tenants in reaching favourable outcomes.

Colm has been a full-time ADR practitioner for over 25 years. Colm received his LLM (ADR) from Osgoode Hall Law School at York University. He holds the FCIArb designation with the Chartered Institute of Arbitrators (UK) and the C. Med-Arb designation with the ADR Institute of Canada (ADRIC).

Colm is an acknowledged Canadian expert in the development of online dispute resolution (ODR) and med-arb processes. His book, ODR – Yesterday. Today. Tomorrow., co-authored with Marc Bhalla, is the first book on ODR published in Canada, and was released on November 15, 2022.

Colm provides both ODR and med-arb training through the Canadian Collaborative for Engagement & Conflict Management and has been a part-time instructor in ADR at the Faculty of Law, Queen’s University and Humber College. He is a frequent guest lecturer at Queen’s University, Osgoode Hall Law School and the University of Toronto and has also presented at continuing education programs and conferences provincially, nationally, and internationally.

Daniella is a Collaborative Family Lawyer, Accredited Family Mediator with OAFM, and owner of Daniella Wald Family Law Resolutions in Toronto. Daniella has practiced in the area of family law since being called to the Bar in 2007, starting out at a boutique family law firm in Toronto before opening her own practice in 2015. Daniella helps families transition through separation and divorce, focussing on client empowerment, self-determination and collaboration, with an emphasis on children’s interests. She strives to provide her clients with flexible and cost-effective solutions, while reducing conflict as they work through their separation issues to reach durable and comprehensive agreements. She is passionate about raising awareness of out-of-court dispute resolution process options for families going through separation.

In addition to her private practice, Daniella was for many years a roster mediator through Mediate393, providing mediation services to clients through the court-based onsite and subsidized offsite mediation programs. Daniella speaks regularly at various courses and continuing education programs, both as a collaborative lawyer and mediator. She has also served as a member of the Board of Directors for Collaborative Divorce Toronto (CDT), Executive Member of the ADR Section of the Ontario Bar Association, Family Law Subject Matter
